response.answer_text: I’m going to take a different kind of stance on this. I want to firstly layout what I would view as a fair definition of ultimate. That would be any sword that had reached a plateau in it’s development. To the point where it is maximized for it’s intended purpose and it would be hard to conceive of a way to reasonably improve upon it’s design for what it is meant to do. While at any place in time a single sword might hold this title. And where over time there may be multiple ultimate swords. One such sword immediately comes to mind as a good example of what ultimate looks like. A weapon of duelists refereed to as a small sword.  Now you might notice that this has a rather odd looking blade. That’s because the blade is a trifoil. It had three lobes or ribs which are not sharp and run the length of the blade. Why would one want a blade that doesn’t cut? because this beast is all about being a Stabby McStabertson. The trifoil shape makes it incredibly rigid for how thin it is. The shape serves to reinforce the strength of that “ultimately” pointy tip. The balance of the blade is very close to the guard. Which means that a slight twitch of the wrist causes the tip to trace a rather large arch at a phenomenal speed. With how thin it is, it’s hard to even see the blade in motion or gauge the tips true distance away from you. While this weapon can do humiliating and possibly debilitating tip cuts. It’s more about ending a fight as quickly and cleanly as possible. With singular precise and leather punctures. It takes a lot of practice, a fast eye, and better than cat like reflexes to defend against such an agile weapon. The swords of duelists eventuated in this design out of a desire to make duels more civilized. Someone going up against one of these had among their concerns, that of leaving the world a pretty corpse. Not maimed and mangled from slashed and hacks, but one ore two clean lethal wounds that didn’t even bleed a whole lot externally. A dignified death. They put so much effort into making the way that the civilized man dies a well mannered affair that one can’t help but respect the elegant death such a weapon delivers. Now again that’s not to say that just because I consider this to be an ultimate sword. That it’s the only such blade I would assign that title. In their own place, time, and context there are plenty of other blades also worthy of holding such esteem. This is just one good example of what I would consider ultimate.

Having tried many numerous swords in sparring, I would have to say the most powerful swords ever produced are those descended from the Roman spatha. These include the Viking or Carolingian sword, the arming sword and the longsword. Now, these swords are the most powerful in my opinion because they offer up tremendous versatility, especially the arming sword and longsword. With those two swords in particular, you are able to perform a murder stroke, which is a technique from the historical manuals in which you grab the blade with your hands, as counterintuitive as it might seem, and smash with the guard. Generally this is a technique used to defeat plate armour, because, unlike in the movies, you are not going to realistically be able to cut through plate armour forged from hardened steel. Ideally you want to either use blunt force against it, or you want to go for the gaps in the armour, in which case you will want to use half-swording, which effectively turns the sword into a close range spear. Yet I prefer the single-handed Viking and arming swords over two handed swords for one reason, which is why I did not list the katana. Swords like the katana and longsword are meant to be two handed, so you cannot use them as genuine one handed weapons, lest they fly out of your hand, and you end up disarming yourself in battle. The beauty about single handed swords is that they have pommels. With a good and strong pommel, you are able to put more confidence into your attacks. On top of that, with your left hand free, you can use that to wield another implement, which can include a dagger, or a second sword (in case you want to evoke the Hollywood image), but more ideally, the implement you would want to use in this case would be a shield. Not only are they solid defensive pieces, but you can also use them as blunt force weapons in their own right. Yet there is another contender for the most powerful sword ever made: the Egyptian khopesh. This is a curved sword, so it’s a natural cutting weapon. I saw these in Prince of Egypt, and thought they looked like a sickle, that it was a very ungainly and ugly weapon. However, in my opinion, after seeing bronze reproductions of it, it’s actually a beautifully designed sword. In fact, it’s almost perfect! You can still thrust with it because the point of the sword forms a straight line with the shoulder, and it also has a hook on the back point, so you can hook an enemy shield and move it aside so that a kill shot can be made.

No, there isn’t. And there is a simple but absurdly strong reason for this: the effectiveness of a sword depends on the context it is used for. Making a straightforward example, we can confront a sword to be used in battle with a sword to be used in duel: which is better? Of corse a battle sword like an arming sword is better in battle, because it’s more solid and allows better parries even against different weapons. A soldier going to battel with a rapier is doomed to see it’s weapon bend in the forse five minutes, and cannot parry most blows from other, heavier weapons. On the other hand, in a duel the fighter with the rapier will most probably win, because of the rapier longer range and deadly speed while thrusting. This exact argument can be made any two types of swords, showing how one can perform better than the other in the right context. This is due to the very reasons upon which the evolution of the sword is based: every time there is a switch of context, e.g. from battle to duel, the sword evolves to be more effective. So it’s straightforward to see that is impossible to state which is the better sword without taking context into account. That said, i can rephrase the question as “which sword berforms better, on average, in most of the possible contexts?” This is a question i don’t feel entitled to give an answer personally, even with my background. But i can tell you this: in the 19th century, an italian fencing master and soldier, Giuseppe Rosaroll, wrote Trattato della spadancia, which is considered the last real fencing treatise. Rosaroll studied all the previous masters in order to find the weapon and style more versatile to be adopted to have an advantage in battle, but also in duels, and it chose a weapon which is fairly similar to a bolognese sidesword, which was a battle and duel weapon also in the 16th century.  I’ll leave to the reader to draw her own conclusions.

May I present the Patton Saber?  Model 1913 Cavalry Saber - Wikipedia I got into sword fighting a while ago. I like longswords which we train most of the time but have to admit something drew me towards sabers. Having to use only one hand and being faster I feel that I can do more things with it than others. Maybe it's just that they don't train it often even though its more often than me, so far. Recently I found out that one of my ancestors (13th degree cousin of my dad's mom) studied fencing, took part in competitions and even designed a saber. That's the 1913 US cavalry saber devlopped by Patton who was the main fencing instructor for the US military and later became a General who became famous in WW2 defeating us Germans. Of course I had to get me one. What a pleasant suprise! The sword was very well engineered. Parts like tang scales guard etc. were all interlocking, easy to disassemble and made of metal. Only the scales were made from Bakelit but framed in a way that they couldn't break. The tang is full and not just a thin rod going through the handle. Overall the construction is more complicated but also more robust than the other sabers of the period which I have seen. However I have to say it is quite a bit heavier than most other sabers but nothing too bad for me. The added length means more reach which is rarely a bad thing. The blade shape is excellent for thrusting and that's something I tend to do. It is sharpened on both sides which lends itself to back cuts to the head which are often surprising to the one receiving them. Also the sharpend back edge should allow an easier recovery after a stab. What I like the most was the generous space on the handle. Most sabers are painfully cramped for me and often I have to bend the guards upwards a bit so they don't cut into my hand. Not so with the Patton saber. It turns out he was exactly as tall as me and big hands seem to run in the family. Patton also wrote two sword fighting manuals which are being reprinted. Even with some sword knowledge one can find a few new things in there or at least get an impression of sword fighting pilosophies of that time in general and Patton in particular. The question requires some more details. Effective at what? Effective means “successful in producing a desired or intended result”, so it is hard to answer what sword is better unless the indented result is specified. Imagine asking a carpenter what tools is more effective at working wood, he would say it depends, if I have to cut wood, a saw is more effective than a chisel, if I have to carve wood, the chisel would work better, a plane would be great to flatten wood or smooth its surface, and even there a scrub plane is more effective to do things than smoothing plane. The same can be applied to swords, if you are a light cavalryman whose main function is to pursue flying, lightly armored infantry, then maybe a saber with a curved blade is the most effective weapon for your goal, if you are a heavy cuirassier whose job is to breach through and route other cavalry, maybe a long, straight blade with a lot of hand protection is the most effective sword. If you are an infantryman fighting the early imperial Roman way, the gladius is right on the money, while if you are fighting in a late medieval melee, maybe you need a longsword. A smallsword is amazing in a duel, or to defend yourself on the street from a couple of footpads, but not great to defeat a gendarme in 16th century armor. Humans are tool users, and we are very good at designing the right tool for the right situation. Just find what the situation is, the details of the problem that needs to be solved and you will probably find that the sword that is most used in that particular situation is the one most effective for that goal.

Two should be considered as ultimate in the sense they were far ahead of their time, and gave their owners almost superhuman powers. The first is the Ulfberht Sword, made near Kassel, Germany from about 800AD to 1000AD. Vikings got a hold of these and used them in their raids on Ireland and other lands. The sword was 1,000 years ahead of its time, with 3x the carbon content and only minute amounts of impurities, or slag. It could just about cut through other swords of the time like magic. No one knows how they were made, as this level of purity needs around 3,000 degrees F, around 3 times what was available at the time. The Ulfberhts were very rare, and highly prized.  The other one is The Irish Sword, so-called by the Irish fighting in their war of Independence from 1919–1923. At the time it was also considered magical. Although not technically a sword, it was called that, so with a bit of poetic license it could be considered as a spiritual follower of swords of the past. It was actually made in America, and had been developed (too late) for WW1 as a “trench broom.” The Irish Sword was the Thompson Submachine Gun. Irish-Americans smuggled about 150 of them into Ireland, where they were magical, with 50 or 100 round drums firing .45 caliber bullets, at a time most soldiers used long and clumsy bolt action rifles. Although most records show them coming in around 1921, the father of a friend confirmed he and others had smuggled a few dozen early prototypes into Ireland in 1920. The few that took part in the Irish War of Independence had a “force multiplyer” effect. They were also (unfortunately) used later by the Provisional Irish Republican Army, a splinter force that fought against the real IRA, and became confused in most people’s minds with the actual IRA, which ended in 1923. When you shoot one, it feels like magic in your hands, and becomes much more so when three or more shooters are standing side by side. They are described in a historical novel called The Irish Sword.  Both of these swords can be seen in the Irish National Museum in Dublin, Ireland.

There are swords that have certain advantages over others based on their shape or construction. However, the idea of there being an “ultimate sword” that is better than all other swords is false. Some swords are better for certain situations than others. I’ll give you some examples.  The katana is perhaps the most egregious example of this. Pop culture is rife with examples of the katana being the ultimate sword. Some people believe that the way it is forged makes it special, and better than other types of swords. The katana is certainly a good sword, but it has its drawbacks just like any other weapon. First, the crossguard on the katana is smaller than on other swords, such as the European longsword. The lack of hand protection is a drawback, especially considering the fact that a favorite tactic of swordsman was to strike at the hand of their opponent to disarm them. Another weakness is that it was brittle compared to other blades because of the high carbon content in the steel. Let’s look at another example shall we?  This is a gladius, which was a short sword employed by the Roman Republic, and later the Roman Empire. The gladius was excellent at thrusting and cutting, but had it’s disadvantages as well. It’s main drawback was it’s lack of reach. With a blade length of around 24 inches, it was best paired with a shield to compensate for it’s length.  Curved swords, such as the falchion, saber, scimitar, etc, were optimized for cutting, owing to the curvature of the blade. Curved blades were used by cavalry, making it possible for them to deal wicked cuts to their enemies as they rode by. However, it had a few drawbacks. The first was that you needed a lot of space to properly wield a curved sword. Cutting requires more space to do properly than thrusting, making it harder to use in confined spaces. Curved blades were also not very effective at defeating armor. With a straight sword, you can maneuver it into the gaps of a suit of plate armor, or stab through chain mail if the tip is narrow enough. You can’t do that with a curved sword. A curved blade is also less versatile than a straight sword. With a straight sword, you can cut with both sides of the blade, thrust, and even flip the sword around and bash someone with the crossguard and pommel. Joyeuse, the coronation sword of Kings of France - reputedly wielded by Charlemagne himself in battle, and last used in coronation of Charles X in 1825. While the hilt is from the later era, the bade itself is a a medieval blade of Oakeshott type XII. A sword is a tool. It is an implement designed to excel at a particular job. It so happens that this job is specifically the disruption of the health of another person, with the distinct possibility of death. A tool is only as good as its user, and even the greatest tools can be rendered useless if improperly employed. You'll not get anywhere banging a screw with a hammer; neither will you make any headway if you insist on applying your sword edge to a man in full plate. With this in mind, there is no satisfactory answer to the question, and the question itself is...problematically formulated. Much as role-playing games would wish otherwise, swords are not ranked by some numerical measure of 'power'. A German-made longsword will kill you just as stone dead as a Greek xiphos, and while a katana may not look at all similar to a gladius, both will still cheerfully take your head off your shoulders. Some swords are better than others in a given role. The gladius was perfect for the Roman legionaries, given their style - employed opposite their shields as a stabbing weapon in close quarters. The estoc worked beautifully against plate armour, employing a stiff point to get through gaps in plate. However, these swords are less than optimal outside their role. The gladius lacks reach, whilst the estoc has no real edge to speak of. A sword is a tool. A tool is only as good as its user. There are no 'powerful swords'. There are only swordsmen, and it all comes down to the swordsman's skill - and maybe, sometimes, the intervention of Lady Luck.

The sword varies from culture to culture, such as Japan with the nodachi, Germany with the zweihander, and Europe with the claymore, but overall the most powerful sword design would have been a great or field sword. There are also other terminologies, but I am talking about a sword that would have been used for battlefield combat as a warrior’s primary weapon. A nodachi would be better for slicing open unarmored or lightly armored foes, while the claymore and zweihander would be better suited for heavily armored opponents. I would say that longswords and two-handed swords like a Zweihander ould be the most effective. Double-edged construction means that false-edge cuts can be just as fatal as true-edge cuts. They have good cutting potential and can be used to thrust with as well. They were effective against leather armour, as well as cloth and similar clothing-like armours. Thrusting techniques allowed them to get around the protection of scale armour, mail hauberks and even plate armour. They are quite heavy, so they can cause significant injury even if they are used to slash at a helmet, though that wasn’t exactly an optimal idea. It was an option though, if need be. Don’t get me wrong, there are plenty of other amazing swords too, but longswords and true two-handers have the advantage due to the sheer number of uses for them and the ways in which they can “defeat” just about any type of armour, even ones they’re not optimised for.

Bear with me a bit. Do you mean to limit discussion to historical examples, only, and exclude prehistoric swords? There are lots of each. Do you mean to make a general wholesale evaluation, of all known swords, as used over the (perhaps) the last 10,000 years? This may seem silly, but each sword type was developed, in part, to contend with the perceived “superior” swords (and other weapons) - on specific battlefields, by specific cultures, by different kinds of combat (calvary vs infantry, etc.), different materials of construction (steel, wrought iron, case hardened wrought iron, tin bronze, arsenic bronze, work-hardened copper, flint, flint-edged wooden, wooden and - believe it or not - even swordfish beaks). The good news (for this blog) is that someone else has done the heavy lifting for you, and written the arquival work you seem to be seeking, imaginatively titled: The Book of the Sword, Sir Richard Francis Burton, pub 1884. (With a pub date like that, you know this is a great find, indeed !) You can get your hands on a copy by using your public library card (online, if you wish) here: Interlibrary loan. The copy for you should be available at your local library branch within 2 weeks of so - there are plenty of recent editions. The book is fabulous, but you very likely will decide that the story of Sir Richard (not the actor guy) is even more amazing. He was one of the British explorers who discovered the source of the Nile River. He is believed to have been the first non-Muslim to undertake a 'Hajj' or pilgrimage to Mecca. He made the (at the time) scandalous translation into English / publication of the Kama Sutra. (It was illegal to publish it in England and the United States until 1962.) He also published the Perfumed Garden' (1886), and a complete edition of the 'Arabian Nights' (1885 - 1888). He was one of those rare humans - a Polyglot - said to personally be multilingual in at least 26 languages – or 40, if distinct dialects are counted. And on, and on. For the Victorian period, his unabashed interest is sex, and sexual practices, especially eastern erotica, led him into some significant scandals - which very likely is why he has been so willingly forgotten. See: Richard Francis Burton - Scandals. “Burton's writings are unusually open and frank about his interest in sex and sexuality. His travel writing is often full of details about the sexual lives of the inhabitants of areas he travelled through. Burton's interest in sexuality led him to make measurements of the lengths of the penises of male inhabitants of various regions, which he includes in his travel books. He also describes sexual techniques common in the regions he visited, often hinting that he had participated, hence breaking both sexual and racial taboos of his day. Many people at the time considered the Kama Shastra Society and the books it published scandalous.” A fascinating man, and brilliant human being - and arguably, the world expert (in one volume) on SWORDS. Unless we start talking about works of fiction there is simply no ultimate sword it all depends on context. A greatsword for example is the best sword for the battlefield as it is so large that it can be classified as a polearm but not in all situations. I would hate to have a greatsword if people are in grabbing distance, and greatswords are cumbersome to carry around as you can’t wear them so for personal self defence they are terrible in these situations for both practical, and/or legal reasons. (You don’t open carry a rifle for self defense same principle here.) They are also shit for horseback it is better to carry a lance, bow, or a gun as your primary in that case. Therefore, they only saw use on the battlefield by specific types of soldier, and by hired bodyguards. To name two more examples, I wouldn’t want an estoc if I know I won’t be fighting against people in armor as they are designed specifically for that purpose. On the flip side, I wouldn’t want to have a tulwar or some other cut centric sword if I am fighting people in armor. I could go for a more versatile sword but the cutting mechanics would change, and in many cases it won’t be as good at either cutting or thrusting. I disagree with Susanna on several counts. The metallurgy and engineering of the dao was solely meant to save time and money. Back to the original question, IMHO, the finest sword ever made was the Goujian. Forged during the Spring and Autumn period, (circa 771–476 B.C.E.), by King Gou (circa 496–475 B.C.E.) of Wei, it was discovered in a waterlogged tomb in 1965 in near perfect condition. It was still incredibly sharp, the inscriptions were still legible, and there was no tarnishing or rust. The sword is elatively short compared to similar historical pieces, the Gouijan sword is a bronze sword with a high concentration of copper, making it more pliant and less likely to shatter. The edges are made of tin, making them harder and capable of retaining a sharper edge. There are also small amounts of iron, lead and sulfur in the sword, and research has revealed a high proportion of sulfur and sulfide cuprum, which gives the sword its rustproof quality. Black rhombic etchings cover both sides of the blade and blue glaze and turquoise is imbedded on the sword handle. The grip of the sword is bound by silk while the pommel is composed of 11 concentric circles. The sword measures 55.7 cm long (21.9 in), including an 8.4 cm (3.3 in) handle hilt, and has a 4.6 cm (1.8 in) wide blade. It weighs 875 grams (30.9) oz. Much of this information came from Goujian: The Ancient Chinese Sword that Defied Time

These are all good answers. Asking which sword is the best is like asking which hand tool is the best. The question must be narrowed down to context and intention before it can even be rationally approached. You might interpret the question as, “if you could only have one sword and you needed a weapon to survive, which would you choose,” the answer to which would perhaps reveal a lot about the speaker’s style and preference. I might even add the snarky reply that the best sword in history is the quarterstaff, but that’s neither here nor there. What I’d like to add is a little about why this is even a question, because it’s a common one, and has been for probably as long as there have been swords. One thing to remember is that although swords are good weapons in a lot of ways, they have always had symbolic meaning that often trumps their practical purpose. Many cultures have looked at the sword as the symbol of nobility, the weapon of the consummate warrior, the symbol of the glories of war. Why? Here are some possible reasons: Swords are hard to make. More importantly, they’re very hard to make well. If you compare a sword with other (often more effective in their context) weapons, like a club, a spear, or an axe, the amount of labor and the amount of expertise required to make one well is exponentially greater. Not only do you need to understand the working of your chosen metal extremely well, you need to have strategies for varying hardness to mix durability and cutting power. You need to know a lot about how a sword is used, and the job that you’re making a specific sword to do so that you can choose the right form and balance.Swords are expensive. Anybody can afford a knife or a cudgel, but only affluent people have generally been able to afford a sword throughout history (particularly a well-made one). It requires high-quality metal in addition to the skilled labor. You can get a decent knife from almost any blacksmith, but the forging of a good blade is a highly specialized skill.Swords by and large serve no other purpose than inflicting deadly harm to other people. Yes, there were hunting swords and the like, but I can’t imagine that something like a boar hunting sword was anywhere near as effective as a spear for that dangerous task. They’re not good as tools like an axe or knife, nor are they very good for non-deadly defense, like the pole weapon of a civilian guard, which can easily be used as a staff to control and bind from afar without deadly intent. In short, if you’re carrying a sword, you are a warrior. In much of the world throughout history warrior plus wealthy means you’re part of the ruling class.The form of a sword, in it’s many shapes and variations, lends itself well to decoration, and symbolism. In Christian Europe, the cruciform sword could be viewed as a religious symbol, for example.All of these things have made the sword a kind of sacred item in many cultures over time. They were valued such that fine examples lent their makers nigh-mythical reputations. In the European tradition, for example, the names of Toledo and Damascus still hold the spell of power gained through being centers for production of quality blades long ago. Every region had its legendary sword type. Every bladesmith had a secret recipe for the most puissant blades. The mysticism and nationalist pride of previous ages lives on. Being connected with the warrior traditions of the ruling class also brings cultural significance that endures long after the sword’s purpose dwindled. A chief example is the samurai, whose prowess as warriors was largely irrelevant for much of early modern history. Until a century or so ago, the samurai class continued to bolster and enhance the sword as a badge of office and social standing (and even into WWII, the sword’s symbolic power transferred to modern military men of rank). Add to all of this the modern, largely uninformed enthusiasm for medieval weapons that sprang forth in wargames and roleplaying games. Lots of folks only know about weapons of war from names and vague descriptions in Dungeons and Dragons books, and have taken the generalizations and misinformation they’ve learned as the gospel truth. This all adds up to the assertion of the best sword being a debate fueled by legend, social institutions, nostalgia, and nationalism. It leads to a pop-culture mysticism about the weapon, generating myriad products named after types of swords and fabulous stories about master smiths hunched over glowing blades, pouring their arcane lore into their working, and imbuing them with otherworldly power.

The Macuahuitl.  The Macuahuitl is a sword used by the Aztecs and Mayan tribes and was the standard close combat weapon. Its sides are embedded with prismatic blades traditionally made from obsidian. The obsidian blade is capable of producing an edge sharper than high-quality steel razor blades. It was capable of inflicting serious lacerations from the rows of obsidian blades embedded in its sides. This obsidian blade can be morphed into a different circular design that looked like scales. The Macuahuitl is described to be similar to a European broadsword. It was noted by the Spanish that the macuahuitl was so cleverly constructed that the blades could be neither pulled out nor broken. According to accounts by conquistador Bernal Diaz del Castillo, the Macualhuitl was sharp enough to decapitate a man and even a horse. “The Indian gave the horse of his antagonist such a blow in the breast that he opened it to the entrails, and it fell dead on the spot. And the same day I saw another Indian give another horse a blow in the neck, that stretched it dead at his feet.”

The Honjō Masamune represented the Tokugawa shogunate during most of the Edo period and was passed down from one shōgun to another. It is one of the best known of the swords created by Masamune and is believed to be among the finest Japanese swords ever made.  Masamune was a Japanese swordsmith that is widely regarded as one of the world’s greatest metallurgists. The exact dates for Masamune’s life are unknown, but it is believed that he worked from 1288–1328. Masamune’s weapons have reached legendary status over the centuries. He created swords known as tachi and daggers. The swords of Masamune have a strong reputation for superior beauty and quality. He rarely signed his works, so it can be hard to positively identify all his weapons.  The most famous of all Masamune swords is named Honjo Masamune. The Honjo Masamune is so important because it represented the Shogunate during the Edo period of Japan. The sword was passed down from one Shogun to another for generations. In 1939 the weapon was named a national treasure in Japan, but remained in the Kii branch of the Tokugawa family. The last known owner of Honjo Masamune was Tokugawa Iemasa. Apparently Tokugawa Iemasa gave the weapon and 14 other swords to a police station in Mejiro, Japan, in December of 1945.  Shortly thereafter in January 1946, the Mejiro police gave the swords to Sgt. Coldy Bimore (U.S. 7th Cavalry). Since that time, the Honjo Masamune has gone missing and the whereabouts of the sword remains a mystery. Honjo Masamune is one of the most important historical artifacts to disappear at the end of World War II.

That being said, there is one sword that I think was better than any other sword at the time it was being made:  Ulfberht swords were the first kind of “Brand Name” swords that we know of. They were made between the 9th and 11th centuries in Europe. The sword shown here is a reproduction. Most Ulfberht swords had the Oakshott Type X blade, but it wasn’t the design of the sword that made them superior. Rather, it was the metallurgy behind them. This is a very subjective question. I will give you one example of why a specific type sword was breakthrough. Swordsmanship, especially 1 handed swords, often takes years, even decades to master. In some regions its a death by a thousand cuts weapon. In Feudal China the evolution of the saber or dao (single edged sword) with its heavier ox-tail design reduced training time as effectiveness increased due to its ability to chop through leather armor as well as deliver decapitating blows. However the invention of the Dadao, which is a 2 handed, bigger, variant of of the oxtail saber, was a game changer. Its weight and strength was capable of slicing through chain and plate armor. Between the dadao and the quandao (a pole arm saber) armies could be trained and equipped in a matter of months instead of years or decades. It is not a fineness type weapon, but a single strike was devastating. Different regions had their breakthrough weapons to deal with advancements in armor and plating. This is just one of many examples.

As with similar questions, “What’s the best guitar?” Or, what’s the best car?”, it’s impossible to say. What would be your criteria? Value? Craftsmanship? Utility? In the very long history of sword-making, these weapons have been made all over the world by various smiths and craftsmen for various purposes ranging from utility in combat to presentation items for kings and emperors. There’s a presentation Scimitar in the Wallace collection that’ been lavished with gold inlay and precious gems in the hilt, and is also a very fine piece of steel and a fully-functional weapon. Would that qualify as “fine”? It’s currently valued in the millions of dollars. Or would a particularly nice Renaissance rapier that has a high-quality “Toledo” blade qualify, as it’s utterly functional? The Japanese smiths lavished enormous care and skill on their blades, but most authorities indicate they are no better than contemporary European or Middle-Eastern blades, as the Japanese were often working with inferior steels.
